Module simplifier
Package ie.gmit.dip

Class ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier

  • java.lang.Object
    • ie.gmit.dip.ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AbstractTextSimplifier<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>,​java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>>
    public final class ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier
extends java.lang.Object
implements AbstractTextSimplifier<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>,​java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>>
    ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier is a concrete and highly specialized class which allows a user to perform a range of operations related to simplifying text, and controlling its color, based on command line input. This is not a generic or highly extensible type, hence it is designated as final such that it cannot form the basis of a subtype in a hierarchy - it is highly specific to performing the specific task requested for this project - mapping a word to its synonym and printing that word in a specific color to a terminal. It is composed of the following types, largely in the form of full composition unless otherwise stated: Two ArrayList types consisting of String types are used to store the text to convert and the converted text. The user has complete control over the text being simplified which can be set from the command line, or, by a setter method should one wish to avoid the command line entirely/run this API in an automated fashion. These ArrayList types are not externally modifiable and are fully encapsulated within this class. A single, fully encapsulated/composed, OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder is used to construct and access a OneToOneMappedThesaurus from files including a thesaurus file, and a list of top words (as identified by Google in this case). In principle it is not straight forward to reconfigure this simplifier with a Thesaurable type that does not perform a one to one mapping of words - the logic required for one-to-many and many-to-many thesaurus mappings is quite different, and potentially complicated in terms of time and space complexity. However, it is entirely possible to substitute both (a) the thesaurusFile (so long as it is arranged as line and comma-separated values) and (b) the list of top words to which the thesaurus should be mapped, and the user has control over these latter two components from the command line. A single, fully encapsulated/composed TerminalInputParser is used to get user input from the command line. These colors are stored and managed via a HashMap of String types entitled defaultColors which is used to assign ANSI color codes to different words depending on their presence or absence in the thesaurus or list of google top words. A fully encapsulated ConfigurableAnsiColorCodeMap is used to set the colors/fonts for printing, and the user has control over the color scheme being used from the command line. Aside from the above composed types, one of central features of this text simplifier is its ability to convert String types. This class delegates responsibility for String conversion to the ConvertibleString and AbstractConverter classes, and accompanying concrete types for the latter (StringCaseConverter, StringColourConverter and StringSynonymConverter). This ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier is therefore strongly coupled to these packages via dependencies in its own convertString() method. Aside from a set of core methods associated with constructing a OneToOneMappedThesaurus, getting command line input, converting strings to their synonym and an appropriate color, there are a set of utility methods which allow the user to run various operations in predefined orders, and these form the basis of an interactive menu implemented in the InteractiveTextSimplifierSession class. The ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier is therefore coupled to and designed to be cohesive with the InteractiveTextSimplifierSession class which allows the user to interact with the ThesaurusMapTextSimplifier without understanding the details of the code implementation. As well as mapping text to a synonym found in the thesaurus, this simplifier also preserves the original case of the text being simplified, as well as punctuation. On the preservation of case, it is impossible to completely retain the original case of a word that was mapped to a word of different length, however, title case is specifically preserved.
    Since:
    JavaSE-11
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Kieran P. Somers
    See Also:
    AbstractConverter, OneToOneMappedThesaurus, OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder, TerminalInputParser, ConfigurableAnsiColorCodeMap, InteractiveTextSimplifierSession, ConvertibleString, AbstractConverter

      • buildThesaurusMap

        public void buildThesaurusMap()
        Method which instantiates/builds the OneToOneMappedThesaurus, with responsibility delegated to the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder.

      • simplify

        public void simplify()
        The convert method is an overridden method which is prerequisite of a type which implements the AbstractTextSimplifier interface. This method is called in order to convert the textToSimplify to the simplifiedText. Responsibility is delegated to the convertString() method, which takes as input the OneToOneMappedThesaurus, the priorityWordSet (e.g. google 1000 words), and the string to be converged. The general running time is O(n) where n is the number of String types to convert. The actual running time is further dependent on the convertString() method, which has more complex behavior.
        Specified by:
        simplify in interface AbstractTextSimplifier<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>,​java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>>
        See Also:
        convertString(java.lang.String)

      • convertString

        public java.lang.String convertString​(java.lang.String string)
        This method is used to configure a ConvertibleString type with a series of appropriate StringConverter types which extend the AbstractStringConverter abstract base class. The primary aim of this method is to correctly configure the case, color, and the synonym that has been mapped, for a given word. The behavior of this method is highly specific to the current application. Depending on the String being converted, a StringSynonymConverter, StringCaseConverter, and/or StringColourConverter can and will be configured, before the String is ultimately simplified/converted. In terms of running times and Big-O notation, most of the important operations are O(1) or O(c) as all Collection based operations, including hasWord, add, getSynonym, contains, are constant time O(1) operations. The exception is the use of the String.equals() method which is O(n) and is sometimes employed to verify if a word has been mapped to itself. The worst case running time of the main block of if-else statements is therefore O(n). The cstring.convert() method invocation has an initial running time of O(n) where n is the number of AbstractStringConverter operations to carry out. Of these AbstractStringConverter types, the worst case performance is O(n) for the StringCaseConverter, which has O(n) running time for conversion of a string to a title case character. The worst case running time for this method can be approximated as the sum of two separate (serial, not tested) O(n) operations where n is the number of characters in the String being converted - one O(n) operation for the String.equals method (if it is invoked), and the other for the StringCaseConverter.convert() method (if it is invoked).
        Parameters:
        string - is the String variable to be converted.
        Returns:
        String the converted String.
        See Also:
        ConvertibleString, AbstractStringConverter, StringSynonymConverter, StringCaseConverter, StringColourConverter

      • setThesaurusFile

        public void setThesaurusFile​(java.lang.String fileName)
        Setter method which allows the user to set the thesaurus input file externally. The buildThesaurusMap() method is invoked if this file is changed. Running time is dependent on the buildThesaurusMap() method, which has further called to the buildMappedThesaurus() of the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder class.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the name of the thesaurusFile to use in the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder.
        See Also:
        OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder

Running time is dependent on the buildThesaurusMap() method, which has further called to the buildMappedThesaurus() of the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder class.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the name of the priorityWordSetFile to use in the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder.

      • setThesaurusFileFromCommandLine

        public void setThesaurusFileFromCommandLine()
        Setter method which allows the user to set the thesaurus input file externally by provision of information at the command line. If the file is valid, the this.setThesaurusFile() method is invoked, which also invokes a re-build of the thesaurus map. Running time is dependent on the buildThesaurusMap() method, which has further called to the buildMappedThesaurus() of the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder class.
        See Also:
        OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder

If the file is valid, the this.setThesaurusFile() method is invoked, which also invokes a re-build of the thesaurus map. Running time is dependent on the buildThesaurusMap() method, which has further called to the buildMappedThesaurus() of the OneToOneMappedThesaurusBuilder class.
        See Also:

      • getTextFromCommandLine

        public void getTextFromCommandLine()
        Utility method which allows the user to provide text at the command line which can then be simplified/converted. Running time is dependent on the parse() method of the IterativeStringSplitter instance, which has complex time dependency.

      • getTextRunConverterAndPrintToScreen

        public void getTextRunConverterAndPrintToScreen()
        Utility method which allows gets text from the command line, runs the converter, and prints the input text and converted output text to screen. Has complex running time, which is dependent on other methods.

      • runConverterAndPrintToScreen

        public void runConverterAndPrintToScreen()
        Utility method which runs the converter, and prints the input text and converted output text to screen. Has complex running time, which is dependent on other methods.

      • printTextToConvertToScreen

        public void printTextToConvertToScreen()
        Utility method which prints the input text to screen Running time is O(n) where n is the number of String types in the textToSimplify ArrayList.

      • printDefaultColorsToScreen

        public void printDefaultColorsToScreen()
        Utility method which prints a description of, and the color of, each type of word to the screen. This legend is used so that the user can interpret the results of String conversion. Each HashMap get call has O(c) running time, and so does this method by extension.

      • printConvertedTextToScreen

        public void printConvertedTextToScreen()
        Utility method which prints the converted text to screen. Has O(n) running time where n is the number of String types in the simplifiedText ArrayList.

      • updateColorFromCommandLine

        public void updateColorFromCommandLine()
        Utility method which allows the user to choose new colors for each type of text from a list of colors in the colorMap. Running time is O(n) where n is the number of colors in the ArrayList of defaultColors and colorMap.

      • queryThesaurusMap

        public void queryThesaurusMap()
        Utility method which allows the user to verify if a word or phrase is in the thesaurusMap OneToOneMappedThesaurus, and to then visualise its color, and the word to which it is mapped. Running time is dependent on the convertString method as described elsewhere.
